Two questions: comparison operations can't be differentiated thru correct? I can't take two vectors, element wise compare them, and define any sort of sensible rules, even if they return a value of the same type (2.0 > 3.0 = 0.0; 3.0>2.0 =1.0). I don't believe I've ever seen that, but am I missing something sort of esoteric? This would be different from control flow I believe.

Does it make sense to use auto diff tools for "boolean differential calculus"? I fell down a rabbit hole while researching for my jsoc proposal. There are, as I understand it, well defined analogues to your typical derivative exist for boolean functions.

If you want you could differentiate through them.
The results is zero basically everwhere and not mathematicaly defined at the equality point. (But there are good reasons to say it is zero there also).
It just might not be useful


Functions with (strictly) Boolean or Integer output have Zero derivatives.
You can perturb the input and the output don't change

Functions with (strictly) Boolean or Integer inputs have no tangent space (what ChainRules calls DoesNotExist, but I want to rename).
You can't perturb the inputs
